notes:
1. Steady Flow Energy Equation (SFEE)

The Steady Flow Energy Equation is the statement of the First Law of Thermodynamics for an open system undergoing a steady-flow process. In a steady-flow process, the properties of the fluid at any point within the control volume do not change with time.

2. The Equation

The SFEE states that the rate of energy transfer into the system (by heat, work, and mass) is equal to the rate of energy transfer out of the system.

$$ \dot{Q} - \dot{W} = \sum \dot{m}_{out} \left( h_{out} + \frac{V_{out}^2}{2} + g z_{out} \right) - \sum \dot{m}_{in} \left( h_{in} + \frac{V_{in}^2}{2} + g z_{in} \right) $$

For a system with a single inlet (1) and single outlet (2):

$$ \dot{Q} - \dot{W} = \dot{m} \left[ (h_2 - h_1) + \frac{V_2^2 - V_1^2}{2} + g(z_2 - z_1) \right] $$
  • $\dot{Q}$: Net heat transfer rate into the system.
  • $\dot{W}$: Net work rate (power) done by the system (shaft work).
  • $h$: Enthalpy per unit mass.
  • $V^2/2$: Kinetic energy per unit mass.
  • $gz$: Potential energy per unit mass.

3. Applications

  • Nozzles and Diffusers: $\dot{Q} \approx 0$, $\dot{W} = 0$, $\Delta PE \approx 0$. The equation simplifies to $\Delta h + \Delta KE = 0$.
  • Turbines: $\dot{Q} \approx 0$ (adiabatic), $\Delta KE \approx 0$, $\Delta PE \approx 0$. Work output is derived from the enthalpy drop: $\dot{W} = \dot{m}(h_1 - h_2)$.
  • Pumps and Compressors: Similar to turbines but work is input. $\dot{W}_{in} = \dot{m}(h_2 - h_1)$.
  • Throttling Valves: $\dot{Q} \approx 0$, $\dot{W} = 0$, $\Delta KE \approx 0$, $\Delta PE \approx 0$. This is an isenthalpic process: $h_1 = h_2$.

solvedExamples.question: Steam enters an adiabatic turbine with an enthalpy of 3200 kJ/kg and leaves with an enthalpy of 2100 kJ/kg. If the mass flow rate is 2 kg/s, what is the power output of the turbine? (Neglect kinetic and potential energy changes).
solvedExamples.explanation:
For an adiabatic turbine ($\dot{Q}=0$) with negligible KE and PE changes, the SFEE simplifies to $\dot{W} = \dot{m}(h_{in} - h_{out})$.
$\dot{W} = (2 \text{ kg/s})(3200 \text{ kJ/kg} - 2100 \text{ kJ/kg}) = 2(1100) = 2200$ kW.

solvedExamples.question: For a throttling valve (like an expansion valve in a refrigeration cycle), which property remains approximately constant across the device?
solvedExamples.explanation: A throttling process involves no work ($ẇ = 0$), is adiabatic ($Ṇ \approx 0$), and has negligible changes in KE and PE. The SFEE reduces to $h_1 = h_2$. Thus, it is an isenthalpic (constant enthalpy) process.
